Fields.DialogueText: Mmm... delightful. Simply heavenly.
Tea time already?
Tea time is whenever good news arrives, Captain, darling. Nothing better than something cool to temper a rush of blood to the cheeks. You've read the latest from Tokyo, I take it?
I see that Japan's pledged more steel to the war effort at sea. Harvested from China's carcass, of course.
We must play the course as it lies, however treacherous the rough.

Fields.MenuText: Does that make me your caddy?
Your negotiations have consequences, you know.
The enemy of my enemy, eh?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, don't be so humble. Ours is a partnership, Captain, even if the left hand sometimes misses a trick from the right.
And you can be an awful stick in the mud sometimes, but even those are useful when you're neck deep in the stuff.
One would think we'd all be friends in these times.
Don't sell yourself short. He was putty in your hands at your last party. Imagine what you could wring out of him with a... softer touch.
Perish the thought! Admiral Nagano is a married man, Captain. I would never interfere with his union, till death do they part.
But neither would I deny an old man the occasional... flight of fancy. Those tend to set other things a-flying. Things that shoot and sail.
Think you'll be able to flirt some more concessions out of Admiral Nagano next time you see him?
Why, Captain, I hope you don't mean to imply anything untoward. I'm simply a gracious and amiable hostess, and my guests may respond in like manner.
*ALARM*
Speaking of things that shoot...
Enough about soft power, Captain. Now's the time for a firmer approach.
@BATTLE
Well, you know what they say about too much of a good thing.
Yes, yes, I'll be easy on his poor old heart.
Still have some of your tea handy?
No home is complete without it. What's on your mind, sugar?
It's been on the crew's mind for some time now. It's about the penguins.
Oh, no - has something happened to my little babies? I hope no one has hurt the precious little dears!
Well, one penguin in particular. He seems to have developed a liking for cigarettes. Specifically, those belonging to our sailors.
Ah, I was afraid of that. Little J.B. can get awfully feisty.

Fields.MenuText: Can't you discipline him?
He's stealing from the crew. That's not feisty, that's criminal.
I'm starting to regret giving animals the run of the ship.

Fields.DialogueText: You and I are the only ones who can. I made them all deck officers, don't you see.
I'll requisition more cigarettes, then, shall I? I promoted him to deck officer, so it's only proper that I share the burden of my decision.
Productivity has soared now that we've farmed out the small and tedious to the cuddly and precious. And it's Deck Officer J.B., come to think of it.
I suppose that's inspiring in a bizarre sort of way.
Some things are universal, Captain, and one of them is that small animals are adorable. Some of my guests come just to see them.
I suppose we can tolerate penguins in the name of international cooperation. I don't know about this one.
Leave that to me. I find they're not so different from people, when you get right down to it. Just got to find their buttons and tap.
I'm curious about what our guests think of the little menagerie you've created.
Well, wonder no longer! My little darlings happen to be the toast of the society pages, Allied and Axis alike.
Should I be offended?
Up to you, honey, but they're also cute. You have that alike.
*ALARM*
Drat. And things were just starting to get interesting.
@BATTLE
I could use some of that tea, Augusta.
Good news?
I'm not cooling down, I'm calming down. I just had to chase Officer J.B. out of the galley with a broom.
Why, you utter brute! Flogging's been banned for decades!
Don't give me that. He was getting into the pickles.
Well, he's got to replace the smokes with something. Poor dear is trying ever so hard to quit lately.
Just the other day he was stealing cigarettes.

Fields.MenuText: This is getting ridiculous. One more incident and he's off the ship.
If one of our sailors did this they'd be thrown in the brig.
I'm starting to miss the cigarette theft.

Fields.DialogueText: Never you fear, Captain. I've got plans for this one that would make Belle Boyd blush!
Our sailors happen to be on their best behavior at all times, Captain! You need never worry about that.
Oh, I'm not. Terrible habit anyway.
I hope your plans for him involve getting him to clean up his act. Aren't you throwing another gala here in the next little while?
Not if there's a penguin crashing the party.
Oh, it's going to be marvelous, Captain! We're so charmed to be in the warm waters of the Mediterranean, at the crossroads of civilizations...
He never could stick to one habit.
You just leave the details to me. If we can make the Morganas tuck tail, a little tuxedo bird will be simplicity itself. Why, he's already dressed for the occasion!
*ALARM*
So are we.
I'm always dressed for these occasions, Captain. I daresay I'm the guest of honor!
@BATTLE
Finally got the penguin problem under control, I see.
Indeed, sugar pie. I'm ordinarily given to a softer touch, but once in a while the hard hand of justice must fall.
Is that what you call a pickle barrel wrapped in chains?
Too much of a good thing, and all that. Think of it like catching an unruly teenager smoking and making them finish the entire pack.
Why didn't you do that with J.B.?
Had the issue been a smidge more pressing, I might have. But that was when I didn't have an important diplomatic function right around the corner.

Fields.MenuText: I just want this madness to end.
There's more to the war than your parties, you know.
Poor thing.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't imagine what you mean, honey. Do I detect a note of sourness?
I hardly think it'd be worth fighting without them to look forward to.
He'll learn his lesson.
I didn't realize I'd walked into a dance lesson. It's not my strong suit.
Walk the deck, my captain lies! I've seen you move when you issue orders I intend to stretch. You've got the fluidity of the Savannah herself.
Enough chit-chat. I've got the gramophone all set up and Gershwin on tenterhooks to accompany us.
What do you mean-
No more questions. I will not attend this party without a suitable partner!
*ALARM*
Well, that doesn't sound like An American in Paris.
Keep the record spinning. We'll wrap this one up quick.
@BATTLE
Interesting choice for the venue.
A passenger liner is just the thing, Captain! Dress her up to look like a riverboat and she'll be a little slice of heaven in the midst of all this hell.
Besides, she was blushing like a thief in church at the opportunity. Some of these Italian girls are quite taken with the South.
Not the way you understand my sisters and me, but we do talk.
And how safe is this location, really?
About as safe as a Georgia boy named Sherman, but I promised her we'd roll out a red carpet in Morgana blood.

Fields.MenuText: You've made it work so far, but your warzone galas make me nervous.
So where are the Morganas?
You couldn't have picked a more sheltered location?

Fields.DialogueText: Honey, it'd be passing strange if they didn't! There's nothing like an undercurrent of danger to remind our feuding guests of the common enemy.
Patience, pet. My less well appointed sisters will be by in their time.
Which way I sail is war, myself am war, to riff on dear old John Milton. These things have a way of finding us. Better to take the fight to them.
Are those the escort ships from the Regia Marina?
Our early warning system indicates otherwise, I'm afraid.
@BATTLE
I wondered why you'd recruited a dog.
Passenger ships have Belles?
Ensign Fluffy Scruff Face is an integral member of my crew and you will address him as such.
Everything in place?
Tablecloths pressed and laid, Cherokee roses crowning every table, door, and hatch... Captain, I do believe I have outdone myself!
You say that every time.
Hun, my best parties are always yet to come! Leave nostalgia to those who peaked early. I haven't the time for it!
Well, it looks like we've got gate crashers.
They'll find my gates decidedly uncrashable!

Fields.MenuText: An exquisite finger painting.
Gunsmoke does make surprisingly good perfume.
It helps to have animals cleaning up after the fight.

Fields.DialogueText: And there's the palmetto bug in the bottom of the pitcher.
Positive associations, Captain - that's what a little dress-up is all about. The next time you go shooting, you think of little old me.
Nature abhors a vacuum, but I can teach it to run one!
So who are we throwing ourselves at tonight?
Has anyone told you that green is not your color?
Don't flatter yourself, Augusta. I know how you work. It's fascinating to watch.
@BATTLE
For once that timing worked out in our favor.
Didn't it just? I've just spoken to the most excitable photographer from the Corriere della Sera. He reckons there's a Mussolini Prize in the pictures he snagged of the Morganas in retreat.
It's definitely an evening for pretty pictures. You clean up nice.
My, Captain, you are hitting the sweet tea hard tonight. I am of course ever the picture of fashion.
Why would I, when I have you to flatter me? In point of fact, there are three guests with whom I hope to strike up an intimate discussion. Him... him... and him.
An American, a German... is that an archbishop?
Bernardini's the Swiss nuncio. The Vatican handles its relations with the INPF through him. As well as more unsavory matters, if the rumors are to be believed.
A little bird told you?
Why, however did you guess?
You have them delivering our mail.
As well as listening in on persons of interest. Common humanity has its uses...
Only you could make war look like a pleasant summer afternoon.
I don't go in for doom and gloom, sweet thing. If you forget the good things you're fighting to protect, you've already lost.
I suppose that explains the sun chair and umbrella.
When the world's on fire, I find a tall glass of iced tea to be the ultimate act of defiance.
Depends on what you found out from the gala.
Ah, how shockingly rude of me! I quite neglected to inform you what it is I've been on the hunt for.

Fields.MenuText: Rude? It's dangerous to the mission.
What might that be?
Did you find it?

Fields.DialogueText: No room for ego, I'm pleased to see... how very Lincolnesque.
Treachery, Captain, fit to put Benedict Arnold right off his eggs.
Not yet, but you may rest assured I'm chasing this particular Jefferson Davis straight to Irwinville.
Have you noticed the Morganas appearing at the most inopportune times lately?
Yes, but I've long suspected there's a certain coordination to their interruptions. And now I've proof of it. Peruse this radio transcript if you would, Captain.
On an open channel, no less. Anyone can listen, including the Morganas, and that is tantamount to addressing those fiends directly.
This is... Augusta, this is a transmission of our patrol route!
Don't they always?
Why didn't you tell me about this before?
This is why I'm out here doing some light reading. I pulled all the transcripts dating back to the party before last. This only started between that one and this previous one.
If there's a leak - and sure as I'm Southron there is - one of my guests is widening it.
One of your guests who was here at both parties.
Hence my interest in those three in particular.
Tell me more later. It looks like your party's over.
One more reason to greet the enemy with drink in hand, Captain... you've something to throw in their face.
@BATTLE
I pulled everything I could on Bernardini. Service history with the Church, financial records... the works.
Ah, lovely! We can have ourselves a little spycraft book club.
You've already gotten this information.
Started as soon as I met the man! I slipped an officer onto his escort ship when the band struck up some Vivaldi.
How did you get a penguin to blend in?
Why, I didn't have to. The advantages of keeping a high profile, darling dear. It gives people something to look at while you cultivate a low one.

Fields.MenuText: How did the penguin know what to look for?
You certainly give people something to look at.
Hide the spy in plain sight. I like it.

Fields.DialogueText: They're more perceptive than you give them credit for, and that is all I'm willing to reveal on the subject.
And you give me blissful things to hear.
You would be surprised how easy it is to create a new normal. Disturbed, even.
Even Morganas?
@BATTLE
You know, I wrote to the Vatican for these papers. It occurs to me that if things keep disappearing, your guests will put two and two together.
Oh, never you mind about their arithmetic. I plan for everything.
*ALARM*
The way I plan for coyotes in the yard. Or would, if I had one.
Nothing.
Don't be so certain, Captain. These Vatican types have had centuries to learn how to conceal...
... Diary entries about canon law. Drat.
At least he was good conversation?
So we left them with an empty drawer for... what, exactly?
You needn't fret about that. If they kept documents of a truly sensitive nature aboard their escort vessels, they wouldn't have done it where a penguin could find them.

Fields.MenuText: So what was the point of sending one?
Then we're back to square one.
Maybe we should have done this my way to begin with.

Fields.DialogueText: Men do get careless, Captain. All it took was one misplaced order for the Yankees to win Sharpsburg.
With all the tools we need to step lightly to square three.
Ask forgiveness, not permission. That is what the Catholic Church is for, after all.
All right, well, even so, there's no reason for us to- gah!
Oh, fiddlesticks! That was the last of my darjeeling.
My fault. I'll get something to mop up with... wait. What's that? There, just below that paragraph about marriage.
They're still going to wonder why the documents went missing.
A quarter hour more of shop talk with that prosaic Papist and I would have dived wrist deep into a ouija board with the spirit of Martin Luther.
About as much as a garden wonders why its flowers get picked now and again. The war doesn't stop just because the belligerents are having themselves a swim.
37... 31... 37... Numbers... coordinates? In invisible ink...
*ALARM*
Ooh, these Morganas are getting the business end of my parasol if they think they're more interesting than this...
@BATTLE
All right. Let's leave aside how uncannily lucky we are that I spilled that specific tea on that specific page.
Let's not and say we didn't. I dipped a few of the others in that spill. Same thing.
On every page?
Except this one. It says "Catch me if you can." In German.
Looks like we were investigating the wrong person.
Then I suppose we move down the list.

Fields.MenuText: We're positive the archbishop's clean?
You don't have to be German to speak German.
I can't help but think that's our mystery man's plan.

Fields.DialogueText: Like a whistle, Captain. I'll have to track down my sources and refine their sense of suspicion.
Das stimmt. But it does help.
It's also our only lead. We'll just have to grab it and pull when the time is right, won't we?
Is this something we can clear up before your next party?
We'll have to, Captain. Some of the guests are taking a rain check already. Seems the Morganas weren't the only ones listening to those open channels.
Quite right, Captain. Though I was so looking forward to meeting the Irish ambassador again...
I'll take a slimmer guest list if it means less civilian risk.
Once this blows over, I'll write to him personally. We'll get you that meeting yet.
Why, you're more thoughtful than a sea breeze on a summer's day. Sets a girl's heart stirring like Spanish moss in the wind.
Stay stirred. We've got company.
@BATTLE
So, the Galite Islands... Not much to look at, are they?
Suppose that's why the Regia Marina picked them for a base. Not much spectacle to distract from a mission.
You underestimate the essential human drive for entertainment, Captain. From here I can point out at least six prime sites for a dance floor.
Is that a mark for or against you when it comes to military strategy?
Why, I'd hope any captain of mine would know where it's appropriate to dance!

Fields.MenuText: From what I know of you... everywhere.
Wherever there's a flat surface and a clear line of sight.
And which animals to have build the dance floor?

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph. I've a sense for these things. We'd all be racing to the ocean floor in 3/4 time if I didn't.
Now you're thinking like a Belle, Captain!
Oh, pshaw. It's simply too grand a task for my menagerie. Really, can you imagine my penguins building anything of that scale?
So we're here now. What did our mystery person want from us?
I'm about as clueless as a puppy in a litter box, Captain. We had a where, but not a who or-
A when.
But if there weren't a specific time indicated... might it not be whenever we showed up?
If that message was meant for our eyes, it'd have to be. Our patrol route's already leaked.
Unless... no, I don't even want to consider the possibility.
What?
Morganas. They're peeping their little heads around La Fauchelle, there. Time we dealt with the issue before us.
@BATTLE
You've been scarce lately.
Schedules don't write themselves, Captain. The dinner and dancing are non-negotiables, of course, but everyone has some fool speech they want to give.
Well, you'll be pleased to know your workload's lightened. The Portuguese just bowed out, citing safety concerns.
What do you mean "improvise?"
That Argentinian beef I was counting on won't be coming in. We'll have to find an alternative, but the very idea of using imitation...
Will the guests even be able to tell?
I certainly will! It's simply improper to settle for less than the best for foreign dignitaries.

Fields.MenuText: What was Argentina's problem?
It's a war. They'll understand if they have to get by with less.
So get some British beef.

Fields.DialogueText: Spooked by the Morganas. What else? Those girls have been following us like absolute golems since the leaks manifested.
Rationing is for those who don't plan ahead. And I plan for everything, Captain!
You might as well speak sign language with your feet. That's easier to interpret than British cuisine.
Much obliged, Captain. By chance, did you close the door when-
Whoa! J.B., get off of-
Well, I brought you some tea. Lots of sugar, just like you like. I thought you could use something cold.
Regrettable, but understandable. We'll have to talk to them some other time. That might leave me time to improvise with the food.
Ooh, he's lucky he's pretty. I should have mentioned, Captain, he's extremely nosy.
At least the tea's safe, but it looks like he got away with some of your papers.
Not a problem. I'll just stop him before he can-
*ALARM*
... Looks like that little rascal just earned himself a new nest. Fine. The guests can subsist on galley fare... somehow.
@BATTLE
Well, I'll be a six-legged squirrel at an acorn sale.
Perhaps I underestimated the prowess of our cooks.
Perhaps you were out of touch. I've read the manifests. Your personal monthly food budget could feed our entire complement for a year.
Now, really, Captain! Is it at all proper to comment on a lady's diet?
It's all in how you frame it. I believe you came up with the "Sailors' Banquet" theme when we had to cut back on our budget for this party.

Fields.MenuText: Someone had to. You were drowning your sorrows.
You can sell anything to the higher-ups if you dress it up as innovation.
Anything to salvage it. This one's important.

Fields.DialogueText: When you're used to luxury, normalcy feels downright squalid.
Isn't that just the way of things? Maybe when you're out of touch, the real world looks brand new.
All my parties are important, sweetheart. This one's just different.
All I know is there's a lot riding on this one. The Italians are calling for a formal inquiry into our little boondoggle to the Galites. We couldn't explain it without revealing our espionage.
*ALARM*
Even so-
I told you they'd like it.
I feel like the optics of a warship maintaining a top shelf bourbon stash would invite plenty of comment.
Rank hypocrisy. They're all at it. The war doesn't stop just because we're all on a pleasure cruise.
Leave it all to me, Captain. I'll just have to dance with the German and Italian envoys tonight.
Ah, but not before a little dinner theater! Esteemed guests, might I direct your attention to our starboard...
@BATTLE
Any luck with the German?
Never you mind about him, Captain. He couldn't spy onions in Vidalia.
That dull, eh?
All shooting and hunting. Clearly one of Göring's cronies. He would not shut up about Carinhall, do you know that? One would think he was a tour guide, bless his heart.
And the Italian?
Entirely uncouth, but all the more malleable for it. A wink here, a refill of wine there, and I extracted a promise of a good word in Rome. In writing.

Fields.MenuText: You're shameless.
There's something special about being flirted with by a heavy cruiser.
Even after dinner was interrupted.

Fields.DialogueText: And you're a bore. Beauty is a weapon, and weapons must be maintained and tested.
You would be surprised how few of them keep that in mind. Some of them insist on seeing the lady and forgetting her armament... more fool them.
I did promise a show, Captain! What sort of hostess would I be if I didn't fulfill it?
That just leaves our American.
Your work.
Our work, Captain. You may be the most important piece of this little puzzle.
Oh, if he's the source of the leak, I'm quite certain our work will be disappointingly simple. He simply can't keep his eyes off me.
I guess someone has to sign off on your requests.
Don't sell yourself short, Captain. I feel like the most eligible Belle at the ball. My dance card fills up quicker than a fortune teller's bingo board.
But I'll have you know that at the end of the day, nothing warms my White-Forster boiler of a heart more than coming home to-
Gah! I thought you got rid of this penguin!
J.B.! Ooh, I've half a mind to throw him overboard with a Sherman's necktie for a life preserver.
Where was he going with those papers?
Knife to my throat, I'd say he's upgrading his nest to a bunker. We're drifting into decidedly thorny territory...
@BATTLE
Practicing your golf swing? You're a long way from the fairway.
I'm practicing my range today, Captain. Accuracy can wait.
You're angry.
I am frustrated, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I think you've made your point.
What's on your mind, Augusta?
Would you prefer to be alone?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm a copperhead with its teeth stuck in a corkboard.
Oh, I wanted so badly to tell you. But then a certain overdressed chicken swept the moment out from under us like Satan's own broom.
Only if you prefer I go full Caligula and upgrade from golf balls to armor-piercing shells.
So we got interrupted by your penguin. Why do you tolerate his behavior?
He's notoriously ungovernable, Captain, but he does have his uses. He's my fastest courier... and did I tell you he turned the German envoy's quarters positively upside down?
During your assignation?
Call it that again and I may just pivot to accuracy drills after all.
Right. Well, I think you may have another reason to keep him around. I found his nest... and what he's been using to make it.
Are these... radio transcripts?
Open channels and closed. Nothing about our following those mystery coordinates.
I can see that.
Intensely perturbed.
Indeed.
Why, I'm a seventeen-year cicada waking up under a sparkling new parking lot.
But those Morganas waiting for us...
Were acting on intelligence from elsewhere, for which the little invisible ink caper was a red herring.
I can tolerate a little skullduggery, Captain, but I draw the line at being led around by the nose.
I'm suddenly afraid for the American envoy.
Oh, I'll treat him right. Like these Morganas, it's up to him what precisely that means.
@BATTLE
So about that next party...
I'm fit to be tied, Captain. My favorite French champagne supplier just pulled out! What am I supposed to serve now?
Water? Call it a temperance theme party.

Fields.MenuText: You think they'd go for it?
Surely we can have one party that doesn't serve alcohol.
Maybe if we rationed your bourbon supply...

Fields.DialogueText: I certainly would not, and that is that. It's hard enough doing without my precious Argentinian beef.
And I suppose we grease the wheels and get our guests talking with soda water? You'd sooner grow roses at the bottom of the Chattahoochee.
That still wouldn't solve the issue. I'm planning something big for our next major refit.
I'm surprised the Morganas aren't attacking our suppliers directly.
@BATTLE
They're shrewd, Captain, but they're not petty. My sources keep me well apprised of their movements, so ambushes are more or less wasted on us. It's morale they intend to wear down.
Oh, very funny, Captain. I might as well call off the dinner and have our guests dress as monks.
Maybe we need to get a little more petty.
Maybe I should throw J.B. at them. Here come some now to tempt me.
That guest list is looking-
Desolate?
I was going to say reasonable.
Oh, have some ambition, Captain. Or at least the good sense to offer comfort to a woman in mourning.

Fields.MenuText: We can't force our guests to be comfortable in a war zone.
Mourning for fancy dinners?
We'll make the seas safe for parties again.

Fields.DialogueText: What am I here for if that's so?
Look beyond the steaks and wine, Captain, difficult though that may be.
Oh, I haven't a doubt in my mind we will... eventually.
Look at it this way. The broadcasts were a red herring. They're tracking us some other way. We've learned that much.
You're right, Captain. I've got to keep these things in perspective.
Focus on that last lead, Augusta. We're doing what we can and we're doing a damn good job of it.
At the very least, I'll cure him of his fixation on me. Poor dear simply hovered like a hummingbird at our last engagement...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Well, damnation of all damnations.
That wasn't such a bad party, all things considered.
Adequacy is a deadlier poison than unsweet tea, Captain. What's the point of living if not to be talked about?
Oh, don't beat yourself up over it. The guests had a perfectly lovely time. Especially that American we've had our eye on.
You turned in early that night, didn't you?
Uh-oh. What did I miss?
Well, I have good news and bad news. Our American is not the spy we thought we'd narrowed him down to be.

Fields.MenuText: Well, now we're really back to square one.
So whose is he?
A stooge like the German, then?

Fields.DialogueText: We've sanded the corners off square one and given ourselves a fine circle to push up a hill till Judgement Day.
Well, he's not one of the Morganas' creatures.
With delusions otherwise, I fear.
And you were able to ascertain that he wasn't in the know about our intel problem.
@BATTLE
We were taking a walk around the deck once the band had started packing up, having the loveliest conversation about home. He's a Georgian too, and proud of it.
Indeed, though he proposed another one.
Another one?
He's a little too proud of his origins, Captain. His kind have some fairly repugnant ideas about who our common enemy ought to be and why we Belles are here.
... I see. America's going to want to know about this.
Some of my countrymen believe they are still fighting a certain war. I'm uniquely situated to disabuse them of such notions.
You didn't hurt him, did you?
I may have spooked at a seabird and knocked him into the ocean with my parasol. He'll dry up on the ride home... by which time the White House will have my full assessment of his character.
So where does this leave us?
No closer than when we started, I fear. At least we can clean up along the way. As now.
And naturally, he felt safe sharing them with a physical embodiment of his home sweet home. But I'm home to many people, Captain, even if he prefers otherwise.
You're missing your usual tea. This must be serious.
Astutely observed, Captain. It'll pass. I was just musing.
That would be ever so kind, Captain. This whole thing's been bothering me since day one.
Not enough willing suppliers to spend it on?
Do you know how much of my personal expenses go toward the upkeep of my menagerie, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I'd really rather not.
Too much.
It's worth every penny.

Fields.DialogueText: Leave a lady's financials to her and we'll get along just fine.
They deserve nothing but the best for their service. Even little J.B.
They're well taken care of, they brighten the mood, and they keep the decks squeaky clean. You'd be hard-pressed to find a better investment.
These days I feel about as helpless as Princess Augusta herself.
My namesake. Had we not discussed her?
You might have brought it up. But we have a way of getting interrupted when it comes to the important things.
I quite agree, Captain. So let me say before that pesky alarm goes off that-
I'll muse with you.
We've been playing catch-up with the Morganas all this time and we've nothing but dwindling parties to show for it. There's talk of trimming my budget, do you hear?
Who?
I'm attracted to you.
-I'm attracted to you.
I'm almost disappointed in how simple that was.
No thieving penguins to distract us, no Morganas to interrupt...
Unfortunately, our impeccable timing has quite expired. We shall unpack this later, Captain, in exquisite detail.
@BATTLE
Going over the guest list for the next party?
From that old Nagano party. No, I am simply... indulging in better days.
Didn't you say you hadn't the time for nostalgia?
Call that a flight of fancy, Captain. It's much easier to soar from one to the other when you've updrafts to coast on.
Now everyone's spooked and our mission's shifted from diplomacy to damage control.

Fields.MenuText: You're outstanding at both.
Maybe a little more focus is what we needed.
It'll shift back.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed, Captain, but I know which I prefer.
I can't help but devote myself in many different directions, Captain. I'm a tent with one stake missing and I'm fluttering to loosen the rest.
We'll shift it. I just wish we knew which way.
I suppose this is what it's like to be Admiral Nagano, Captain. Once the glitz and flirtation wears off, a man wakes up and remembers the promises it drove him to make. Whether he could or not.
I just never thought there could be too much of...
Careful! You almost spilled your tea just now.
@BATTLE
Too much of a good thing, eh?
You're going to have me committed, Captain, but to hell with the tea! I've just solved our little dilemma!
How?
Call it nostalgia, Captain, darling. Now, speaking of things I couldn't do without you... we've Morganas ahead and my parasol's positively quivering with anticipation.
You can't be serious.
Serious as a shipboard plague, Captain. Who was on courier duty during the last party?
And the one before that? And the one before that?
Not just a penguin, Captain. One with a weakness for cigarettes. Easily bribed and with a nose for-
-Transcripts. Coordinates. Logs.
Hadn't I always bragged about the uncommon intelligence of my darlings?

Fields.MenuText: Uncommonly traitorous.
Something tells me you should be more discriminating in your choice of darling.
So get rid of J.B. and we get rid of the leak.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, dear, they're animals. They fall right in love with whoever feeds them. Or indulges their nasty habits.
Oh, don't be so dour, Captain. I am quite confident in my taste in darlings.
Don't worry about that, darling. I already have a plan in motion.
So if it isn't one of your regulars plying him with cigarettes, who is it?
One of the help, I expect. Now that I know where to focus, it will be simplicity itself to determine which of our crew or the guests' entourages is our miscreant.
@BATTLE
Officer J.B.
I don't believe it. All this time we've been thwarted by a penguin.
But if we get rid of the penguin-
Oh, boo, Captain, you never did like him anyway. Snip the serpent's tail and the rest of him will crawl off to do heaven knows what. No, we scoop up the whole thing at once.
*ALARM*
I'll keep it under my hat until the party. We continue as before.
Like nothing's changed in the slightest! Oh, and speaking of... well, we'll deal with that later.
So you know where J.B. is right now?
I know where everything is aboard me, Captain. It's just a matter of focus. Once I narrow his location down I can just pop in and snag our conspirators like a trapdoor spider.
So what do we do until then?
What else, Captain? We dance.
Really? Nobody to flirt with? No lonely ambassadors or admirals?
Are you going to sweep me across the dance floor, Captain, or is that gift horse going to languish in the dentist's chair?
At long last, my dance card is wide open.
So why would anyone leak our plans to the Morganas?
Honestly, Captain, must we bring our work with us?

Fields.MenuText: One corner of your mind is occupied with a certain penguin.
Where I am is war, myself am war, remember?
A captain's work is never done.

Fields.DialogueText: A mosquito buzzing at my ear, Captain, soon to be crushed. I pledge here and now never to crush you.
You're either well read or you have an impeccable memory. Both have their uses.
Oh, I almost hate to concede you that point. It gives me the shivers when you have that steely look in your eyes.
Your parties don't count as work to you?
They have their military and diplomatic applications. But I'm of the opinion that if you do what you love, you never work a day in your life.
The lengths you go to to do what you love... they have me convinced otherwise.
Neigh.
Why, Captain, I daresay I've inspired you awfully.
It's easier to run a war when you've got a delicious peace party to fight for.
Easier to throw one when you can fight back to back.
I thought you had eyes everywhere. Including in the back of your head.
Well, right now I'd say they're all focused on...
Augusta?
J.B. We'll continue this courtship later.
Damn penguin...
*ALARM*
Damn Morganas!
@BATTLE
Mail's here.
Oh! Let me see...
A Mussolini plant?
I doubt we'll ever know. The Pope himself ordered our spy to a life of "prayer and penance."
I knew there was still a use for that barrel.
Did you have to lock J.B. in there with him?
No.

Fields.MenuText: Isn't that cruel and unusual?
It certainly gave the Regia Marina a laugh when they picked them up.
You're not going to miss him?

Fields.DialogueText: Cruel and unusual would be shipping them both to the Vatican with no return address, and I must admit I was tempted in that direction.
We could all use one in these times. If you don't laugh, you cry, and I know which one is better for the soul.
The way you'd miss a troublesome younger sibling. He'll be well provided for in the Giardino Zoologico di Roma... in a smoking enclosure, naturally.
True believers are out there... apocalypse nuts, misanthropes, the like.
Like you with your champagne.
Quiet, you.
I just don't understand what could possess someone to turn traitor for the Morganas.
That letterhead... yes, it's Archbishop Bernardini. He's written to formally apologize for his staff.
And pickles.
It could just as easily be a fascist plot. The war on land doesn't end just because we're all threatened at sea.
Wars are declared by governments, but they are fought by people. And people can be persuaded all kinds of different ways. Everyone has their desires... or their breaking points.
Make me.
*ALARM*
Or don't.
Do continue to needle me, Captain. I'm certain I'll think of a reason that may satisfy us both...
@BATTLE
You know, you never explained what you meant about the princess.
Who?
Augusta.
Indeed. My namesake, Captain... I suppose you wouldn't have heard of her.
Why not?
Oh, it's a boring story. Nothing you need busy your pretty head over.

Fields.MenuText: Nothing about you is boring.
After all this spy nonsense I could use something boring.
I like it when you call me pretty.

Fields.DialogueText: You always know just the right thing to say.
Well, settle in, Captain, because there's more than a little tragedy involved as well.
And thank goodness you are, Captain.
Princess Augusta of Wales was a failure. She never made any impact on anything, and she died to be forgotten.
She didn't even know the language of the country she was to rule, and she never changed a single mind.
And I have made it very clear to myself and to the world in general that I will be nothing like her.
As a leader, as a statesman, and as a person, she was little more than a forgettable blip in history. At most, a name linking two kings.
The city was named for her.
And I, by proxy.
I never would have known it if you hadn't told me. I see much more than a princess in you, Augusta. I see a queen. And not one of those that comes by the title by marriage.
You move heaven and earth to get what you want. For someone who can't leave her ship, that's pretty remarkable.
What's remarkable is a captain who knows to step out of the way when I move it.
And into your arms.
Captain, if you are trying to supplant tea as my primary source of sweetness, I must inform you that you're chipping away at Stone Mountain with a needle.
I've got time.
Well, let's go give you some more.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
All right, I think I've just about got this seating chart all hammered out.
Yes, hail the conquering heroes and all that foofarah. I'm sure you'll be the life of the party, darling.
Thanks, but I know I won't be. All of this just feels so inconsequential in the face of war.
That is exactly why I push you to socialize, darling. I know you focus so heavily on your work.
It is good to remove yourself from that environment when one is given the chance for relaxation.
And besides, now that the spies have retreated to their spy holes, we should have all the help we need in the Mediterranean.

Fields.MenuText: I've said it before and I'll say it again, but your contributions to the Fleet are invaluable, Augusta. I don't know what we'd do without you.
Thank you. I could never grasp the vagaries of politicking and socializing the way you have.
Good job. I feel a lot better about our chances out there now.

Fields.DialogueText: Anything for you and my crew. And for my sisters in the Fleet.
The key is to stare menacingly while accidentally holding a carving knife just so.
Oh, darling, we were always going to win. This just ensures that the wicked girls will be rousted from every billet they find.
Still, it's good to know that whatever happens next, we're facing it together.
There's no captain I'd rather have, Captain. I could not imagine a side I would rather be at.
I can't imagine this war without you, Augusta.
Then don't. I daresay I'm more than happy for you to look at me.
Don't forget the triumph.
Well, while we're at it... you may want to change that seating chart. A certain Francis Cremins RSVP'd late.
The Irish ambassador to Switzerland! Oh, Captain, you didn't! I've wanted him back aboard for ages...
I'm told he prefers "Frank."
Quite right. And you prefer... sugar? Darling? Honey bear?
All of the above.
